title: Hilbert's Vision
content:
Hilbert posed this problem in 1900: 'For any given number field, to find the most general reciprocity law which governs the behavior of the n-th power residue symbol.'

He was asking: Can we generalize Gauss's beautiful quadratic reciprocity law to higher powers (cubic, quartic, etc.) and to arbitrary number fields?

The answer took 27 years and the development of an entirely new field: class field theory.
mathContext: Hilbert sought a general formula for when $a$ is an $n$-th power residue modulo a prime ideal $\mathfrak{p}$ in a number field $K$.

title: Quadratic Reciprocity
content:
**Gauss's Golden Theorem** (1796): For distinct odd primes $p$ and $q$:

$(p/q)(q/p) = (-1)^{\frac{p-1}{2} \cdot \frac{q-1}{2}}$

This is the simplest reciprocity law, governing when a prime is a quadratic residue (perfect square) modulo another prime.

Gauss called this his 'golden theorem' and gave 8 different proofs during his lifetime.
mathContext:
$(p/q) = 1$ means $p$ is a quadratic residue mod $q$: $\exists x : x^2 \equiv p \pmod{q}$

$(p/q) = -1$ means $p$ is a quadratic non-residue mod $q$

title: First Supplementary Law
content:
**First Supplementary Law**: $-1$ is a quadratic residue mod $p$ if and only if $p \equiv 1 \pmod{4}$.

This tells us when the equation $x^2 \equiv -1 \pmod{p}$ has solutions. For example:
- $p = 5$: $2^2 = 4 \equiv -1$, so $-1$ is a QR
- $p = 7$: No solution exists, so $-1$ is a QNR

title: Second Supplementary Law
content:
**Second Supplementary Law**: $2$ is a quadratic residue mod $p$ if and only if $p \equiv \pm 1 \pmod{8}$.

For example:
- $p = 7 \equiv 7 \pmod{8}$: $3^2 = 9 \equiv 2$, so $2$ is a QR
- $p = 5 \equiv 5 \pmod{8}$: No solution, so $2$ is a QNR

title: Higher Reciprocity Laws
content:
Before Artin's general solution, mathematicians discovered reciprocity laws for specific cases:

**Cubic Reciprocity** (Eisenstein, 1844): In $\mathbb{Z}[\omega]$ where $\omega = e^{2\pi i/3}$, there's a law for cube residues.

**Quartic Reciprocity** (Gauss, Eisenstein): In $\mathbb{Z}[i]$, the Gaussian integers, there's a law for 4th power residues.

These required moving from $\mathbb{Z}$ to rings of algebraic integers!
mathContext:
For cubic reciprocity, work in $\mathbb{Z}[\omega] = \{a + b\omega : a, b \in \mathbb{Z}\}$

For quartic reciprocity, work in $\mathbb{Z}[i] = \{a + bi : a, b \in \mathbb{Z}\}$

title: The Artin Symbol
content:
The **Artin symbol** (or Frobenius element) $(L/K, \mathfrak{p})$ is the key innovation.

For a prime ideal $\mathfrak{p}$ of $K$ unramified in an abelian extension $L/K$, the Artin symbol is the unique automorphism $\sigma \in \text{Gal}(L/K)$ satisfying:

$\sigma(x) \equiv x^{N\mathfrak{p}} \pmod{\mathfrak{P}}$

for any prime $\mathfrak{P}$ above $\mathfrak{p}$.

This generalizes the Legendre symbol to arbitrary extensions!
mathContext: For $L = \mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{p})$, the Artin symbol at $q$ equals the identity iff $(p/q) = 1$.

title: Artin Reciprocity Law
content:
**Artin Reciprocity** (1927): For an abelian extension $L/K$ of number fields, the Artin map

$\mathfrak{p} \mapsto (L/K, \mathfrak{p})$

extends to a surjective homomorphism from the ray class group $C_{\mathfrak{m}}(K)$ to $\text{Gal}(L/K)$.

This is THE answer to Hilbert's 9th problem. Every reciprocity law follows from this single principle!

title: Quadratic as Special Case
content:
Artin reciprocity recovers quadratic reciprocity when specialized!

For $K = \mathbb{Q}$ and $L = \mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{p})$:
- $\text{Gal}(L/K) \cong \mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}$
- The Artin symbol $(L/K, q)$ equals identity iff $(p/q) = 1$

The reciprocity law then follows from properties of the Artin map and the structure of ray class groups mod $p$.
mathContext:
$(\mathbb{Q}(\sqrt{p})/\mathbb{Q}, q) = \text{id} \Leftrightarrow (p/q) = 1$

This connects Galois theory to residue symbols!

title: Beyond Artin: Langlands Program
content:
Artin reciprocity is the **abelian case** of a much grander vision: the Langlands program.

Started by Robert Langlands in 1967, this program seeks reciprocity laws for **non-abelian** extensions, connecting:
- $n$-dimensional Galois representations
- Automorphic representations of $GL_n$
- $L$-functions and their analytic properties

This is one of the most ambitious programs in modern mathematics, still actively researched.
mathContext:
Langlands correspondence (conjectural):

$\{\text{Galois representations } \rho: G_K \to GL_n(\mathbb{C})\} \leftrightarrow \{\text{Automorphic representations of } GL_n\}$

title: Modular Arithmetic Examples
content:
We verify properties underlying the reciprocity law:

**Residue classes mod 4**: $5 \equiv 1$, $3 \equiv 3 \pmod{4}$

**Residue classes mod 8**: $7 \equiv 7$, $5 \equiv 5 \pmod{8}$

**Sign computation**: For $p=3, q=7$:
$(p-1)/2 \cdot (q-1)/2 = 1 \cdot 3 = 3$ (odd)

So $(3/7)(7/3) = -1$ by the main reciprocity law.
mathContext: The sign factor $(-1)^{(p-1)/2 \cdot (q-1)/2}$ determines whether the Legendre symbols are equal or opposite.

title: Takagi's Class Field Theory
content:
**Teiji Takagi** (1920) developed class field theory, providing the foundation for Artin's work.

Takagi proved the **existence theorem**: every finite abelian extension of a number field $K$ corresponds to a congruence subgroup of the ray class group.

This gave the structure, but Artin's reciprocity law provided the explicit isomorphism.
mathContext: Takagi's theorem: Abelian extensions $L/K$ correspond bijectively to open subgroups of finite index in the idele class group $C_K$.
